metadata.title: Titania nanotubes supported platinum catalyst in CO oxidation process

Fig. 1 Characteristic micrograph of initial TiO2 nanotubes. Arrows 1 and 2 demonstrate a single nanotube associate and a circular cross-section (open ends), respectively. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of (a) as-prepared TiO2 nanotubes, (b) and (c) Pt/TiO2 nanotubes calcined at 500°C and 600°C respectively, (d) Pt/TiO2 nanotubes after CO oxidation for 6h (up to ∼800°C), and (e) Pt/TiO2 nanotubes after calcination at 800°C. All the calcinations (b, c and e) were performed for 2h in air. Fig. 3 The curves (a) of TG (main panel) of as-prepared TiO2 nanotubes. The micrograph (b) of the nanotubes calcined at 600°C for 12h in air. Fig. 4 Micrographs of Pt/TiO2 nanotubes catalyst: (a) before the catalytic process (arrow shows initial Pt clusters) and (b) after 6h of process. Fig. 5 XPS spectra of the platinized TiO2 catalysts. The Pt 4f cores are given for: (1) Pt/TiO2 nanotubes, and (2) Pt/TiO2 rutile. Fig. 6 Catalytic activity (CO conversion) α—normalized on BET areas of the pure supports: (a) pure TiO2 rutile (10m2/g) and (b) TiO2 nanotubes (110m2/g). Fig. 7 The change of catalytic activity α of Pt/TiO2 nanotubes composite (a) after calcinations at 400°C for 12h, (b) in the second run, and (c) in the first run. Fig. 8 Micrographs of (a) Pt/TiO2 nanotubes after the catalytic process (arrow shows initial Pt clusters), (b) the Pt/TiO2 nanotubes and (c) Pt/TiO2-rutile after 12h of calcinations in air at 800°C. Fig. 9 XPS spectra of the Pt/TiO2 nanotubes catalyst after oxidation of CO in the reactor for 6h. (a) A shift of O 1s core peak after the calcinations at 500°C and catalytic CO conversion. The dotted lines show components of profile fitting. (1) Initial probe, (2) calcinations at 500°C in air, and (3) after superheating in CO/O2 atmosphere. (b) The Pt 4f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2 shoulders for platinum 4f core of Pt/TiO2 nanotubes after catalytic processing. Table 1 Characteristics of catalysts and their temperatures of initial conversion. Grigorieva a ⁎ Eugene A. Goodilin a b Lyudmila E. Derlyukova c Tatyana A. Anufrieva c Alexey B. Tarasov a Yuri A. Dobrovolskii c Yuri D. Tretyakov a b a Materials Science Department, Lomonosov Moscow State University, 119991, Leninskie gory - 1, Moscow, Russia b Chemistry Department, Lomonosov Moscow State University, 119991, Leninskie gory - 1, Moscow, Russia c Institute of Problems of Chemical Physics, 142432, Acad. Semenov av. - 1, Chernogolovka, Russia ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +7 4959394729; fax: +7 4959390998. Graphical abstract Catalytic activity of TiO2 nanotubes and titania-supported platinum catalysts was examined for carbon monoxide oxidation process. It is shown that titania nanotubes modified with 1.5wt.% of 1–5nm platinum clusters reveal notable catalytic activity already at room temperature. Catalytic activity of TiO2 nanotubes and titania-supported platinum catalysts was examined for carbon monoxide oxidation process. It is shown that titania nanotubes modified with 1.5wt.% of 1–5nm platinum clusters reveal notable catalytic activity already at room temperature contrary to titania or platinum itself. The catalyst behavior was analyzed using TEM, XRD and XPS techniques to find out if structural peculiarities of titania nanotubes may contribute to the catalysis at low temperatures. Keywords Titania nanotubes Platinum catalyst Carbon monoxide oxidation Metal–support interaction 1 Introduction Titanium (IV) oxide is one of the most promising materials widely applied as catalyst supports [1], photocatalysts [2], gas sensing elements [3], and anode materials for batteries [4]. Titanium dioxide supported noble metal catalysts, such as gold [5], silver [6] or platinum [7], are effective in many important processes, such as selective oxidation and hydrogenation, automobile engine exhaust systems [8], etc. Currently, titanium dioxide nanotubes are examined in respect with their possible prominent applications. Principal advantages of the nanotubular form seem to be related to the property that a high value of specific surface area and structural peculiarities increase the number of potentially active centers in the nanotubes. The crystal structure of TiO2 nanotubes seems to be a derivative of monoclinic H2Ti3O7 titanic acid [9] with a relatively high concentration of Brønsted acid sites at Ti–O surfaces. Lewis acid sites are also modified in comparison with TiO2 or titanic acid as a result of scrolling of Ti–O planes. Another property of TiO2 nanotubes is low tendency of self-texturing, as compared to some other types of nanotubes [10]. TiO2 nanotubes are always open-ended and accessible for the interaction with gaseous substances. Such nanotubes are isostructural to titanic acid or even to sodium titanate, in spite of that titania nanotube is a commonly used term for these materials. In the recent paper by Formo et al. [11], the authors applied extruded TiO2 nanofibers, modified with platinum nanoparticles, for preparation of a membrane with high catalytic activity in hydrogenation of methyl red. Hydrated ruthenium oxide deposited onto TiO2 nanotubes was also reported to be a promising catalyst for oxidation of alcohols [12]. Recently titania nanotubes were proposed as an efficient support for palladium nanoparticles [13]. Authors of another publication [14] studied the deposition of a number of metals using impregnation technique. In the paper [15], a new competing reaction pathway during CO oxidation with a bicarbonate intermediate product formation was observed for titania nanotubes supported gold nanoparticles. However, in general, noble metal catalysts supported on 1D titania nanostructures are still rarely studied. In this work, nanoparticles of platinum were chemically deposited onto a number of titania samples including nanotubes to compare their catalytic activity and clarify possible reasons of this activity; advantages and disadvantages of the nanotubular titania as a platinum catalyst support. 2 Experimentals and methods Nanotubular titania was prepared using a hydrothermal technique. 4g of polycrystalline anatase powder (Sigma, T8141) was stirred with 35ml of 10M water solution of sodium hydroxide for 24h. Then the mixture was autoclaved at 180°C for 48h. The derived product was washed repeatedly with diluted nitric acid and then deionized water until pH has reached 6. The concentration of sodium ions in final samples was about 10wt.%, according to EDX data. To ensure the highest yield of nanotubes in this process, the hydrothermal treatment was carried out for 48h while only 20h is known to be sufficient for TiO2 nanotube preparation. An increase of preparation temperature decreases the yield of nanotubes [9]. Deposition of platinum clusters onto TiO2 sample surfaces was achieved by reduction of diluted aqueous solution of hexachloroplatinic acid with suspended nanonotubes by formalin under vigorous stirring at 80°C for 45min and UV-irradiation with a wavelength of 254nm. The standard Pt/α-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared in the same manner using granulated alumina with a BET area of 140m2/g. The total percentage of platinum on the support was 1.5wt.%. The precipitation of platinum was realized for all the studied samples in alkali media at pH = 10, because this technique leads to well-dispersion of metal particles [16] and the alkali media usually removes chlorine ions from the surface. The samples were examined by XRD using Rigaku D/MAX 2500 (Japan) with a rotating copper anode (CuKα irradiation, 5–80° 2Θ range, 0.02° step). The microstructure of the samples was studied using a transmission electron microscope Leo 912 AB Omega (Germany) with a LaB6 cathode and accelerating voltage of 100kV and a scanning electron microscope Leo Supra 50VP (Germany), equipped with an EDX detector (Inca, Oxford Instruments). A local chemical analysis of the samples was realized using data over 5–10 points. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were measured by the LAS – 3000 (“Riber”) spectrometer, equipped with a semispherical analyzer OPX – 150 with a retarding field. For excitation of photoelectrons, AlKα (1486.6eV) irradiation was applied (cathode-ray tube voltage 12kV, emission current 20mA). Calibration of photoelectron peaks was performed against 1s—line of carbon with a binding energy of 285eV. The samples were transferred into the vacuum chamber of the spectrometer immediately after quenching the experiment out or using a container filled with dried nitrogen. Specific surface areas and pore sizes were determined using capillary nitrogen adsorption with the Nova 4200e setup (Quantachrome Instruments). Adsorption–desorption isotherms were analyzed in terms of the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller method (BET). An analysis of catalytically activity of the materials was focused on the model reaction of carbon monoxide oxidation. All the experiments were performed in a dynamic regime in a tube flow reactor. The temperature was controlled by a temperature sensor in the furnace and, independently, in the center of catalyst powder. A continuous flow of an inert carrier (dried nitrogen or helium), containing the reactionary mixture, passed through the reactor with a fixed flow rate of 60ml/min in all the experiments. The total weight of the catalysts was typically about 50–60mg. The probes were analyzed at the outlet using chromatograph “Chromatech Crystall 500.1” (Russia), possessing a column of 0.6m in length, filled with molecular sieves (pore diameter of 5Å). The volume of analyte probe was about 0.1cm3. The CO concentration varied in the range of 1–20%, the oxygen concentration was 10–40%. The reaction was carried out at 1atm, a decrease of pressure was taken into account in the equation for CO conversion. The ratio of CO/O2 at the inlet of reactor was of 1:2 or 1:10, i.e. the experiments were performed in excess of oxygen to CO. We added to the probe 0.4g of glass beads per 1mg of the probe to avoid overheating. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The catalyst characterization An overall microstructure of produced titania nanotubes is given in Fig. 1 . It seems that the applied hydrothermal treatment resulted in a complete transformation of the initial precursor into the nanotubular form of titania. The nanotubes are about 50–200nm in length, their mean outer diameter was found to be about 9nm, while the inner space seems to be half of this value. Each nanotube consists of 3–5 layers and has open ends. The nanotube ensemble demonstrates no extended texturing and thus almost each nanotube is available for participation in heterogeneous processes. It is known that Ti–O walls of nanotubes are isostructural with the (100) plane of H2Ti3O7 titanic acid, scrolled along the 〈001〉 direction [9]. The XRD pattern of pure nanotubes is shown in Fig. 2a, it reveals a layered structure of product and absence of a large amount of impurity phases. None of anatase reflections were observed, which usually occurs at high temperatures of hydrothermal treatment. A specific surface area of produced nanotubes was found to be 110±10m2/g. A pore diameter distribution was estimated to range from 2nm to 5nm, these values are close to the inner diameters of nanotubes observed by TEM. We also found a wide distribution of macropores, corresponding most probably to intergranular cavities existing in the nanotube ensembles. The specific pore volume was found to be 0.4m3/g. The characteristics of nanotubes depend strongly on preparation technique, so the thermal stability of the produced nanotubes was studied using XRD, TG–DTA and XPS to find out the working range of the catalyst. The TG and DTA curves are given in Fig. 3 . Presumably, the loss of adsorbed water occurred in the temperature range of 100–150°C, the rest of water is lost above 550°C, resulting in sample recrystallization (Fig. 3b). Thus, it is evident that heating above 550°C causes degradation of the nanotubes. In our experiments we have chosen the chemical precipitation technique to deposit platinum nanoparticles, as a much more effective approach, compared to wet impregnation [14]. This approach leads to a better deposition of metal. We deposited platinum using formaldehyde as a reducer; this reaction occurs better in alkali media. The platinum nanoparticles cover outer surface of TiO2 nanotubes rather evenly (Fig. 4a), resulting in no change of the crystal (XRD) structure of the nanotube. The similar deposition technique was realized for TiO2 nanotubes without sodium under similar conditions. The same procedure performed with rutile and anatase produced large crystallites covered by platinum nanoparticles (Fig. 4b). The percentage of platinum deposited onto polycrystalline anatase and rutile was a little bit lower than for nanotubes, but not less than 1wt.%. The control of platinum percentage in the probes was realized by varying of H2[PtCl6] concentration. The deposited platinum nanoparticles are not facetted, but rounded. A statistical analysis of the TEM micrographs reveals that the average diameter of Pt nanoparticles has to be 3±2nm. Fig. 4a demonstrates the uniformly sized nanoparticles deposited onto a bundle of TiO2 nanotubes. At the same time, direct observation of sample microstructures (Fig. 4) revealed a comparable size of the platinum nanoparticles in all of these cases. According to nitrogen adsorption data (BET), the specific surface areas of the probes with platinum increased by less than 10m2/g. The dispersion of platinum, according to the BET data, was in the range of 500–800m2/g. The TPR-H2 measurements, carried out with platinized TiO2 nanotubes, showed a decrease of adsorption capacity of H2 by a factor of 10 in the temperature range of 60–700°C [17]. Overall platinum content in the samples was about 1.5wt.%, as determined by EDX and XPS measurements. XRD patterns of platinized samples are similar to the data for their non-platinized equivalents, confirming low concentration and small sizes of platinum particles as well as stability of the sample structure during the platinum deposition process. In order to find out possible advantages of TiO2 nanotubes prior to polycrystalline rutile and anatase, different samples of Pt-modified or as-prepared titania were investigated (Table 1 ). The valence state of sample constituents analyzed by XPS (Pt 4f cores, Fig. 5 ) makes it possible to assume that the oxygen to platinum ratio exceeds 1. 3.2 The catalytic experiments Under heating and self-cooling of the reactor all the platinized catalysts demonstrated a hysteresis effect of the temperature dependence CO conversion. Such behavior is characteristic of platinum catalysts [18]. The as-modified (platinized) TiO2 nanotubes demonstrated high initial catalytic activity in the CO oxidation process even at room temperature (Table 1), with almost 100% of CO conversion α at 40±5°C [19]. The temperature of stationary activity of the probe was found at 120°C. The other platinized catalysts such as Pt/TiO2 anatase, Pt/TiO2 rutile revealed the stationary activity starting from 200°C only. A well-crystallized α-Al2O3 with a low own catalytic activity served as a model inert support for Pt nanoparticles to clarify the importance of joining titania and platinum in the Pt/TiO2 catalyst [20]. This support demonstrates a weak interaction with a metal component and should be used as a proper reference for nanotubes because of similar BET areas. This Pt/α-Al2O3 sample has shown appreciable conversion at 270°C only, while 100% of carbon monoxide conversion was found above 350°C. We carried out the CO oxidation over non-platinized probes to analyze a possibility of conversion on TiO2 surfaces of different nature. Non-platinized TiO2 probes also give 100% of CO conversion at high temperatures only (Table 1); CO conversion for both TiO2 rutile and anatase was determined to be above 350°C. The conversion level of CO on unmodified rutile reached 14% at 470°C. The same behavior we observed for pure anatase, i.e. the 100% conversion level, was not achieved at all for both rutile and anatase probes. The unmodified TiO2 nanotubes showed the beginning temperature of conversion at about 140°C (Table 1). The temperature dependences of CO conversion level for the two samples are demonstrated in Fig. 6 . This data shows a relatively low activity of either TiO2 samples or nanodispersed Pt itself and thus suggests a synergetic effect of platinum and titanium dioxide in the catalytic process. This effect could be probably related to the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, since similar results were reported for metal nanoparticles supported onto polycrystalline TiO2 [21]. It seems that the biggest synergy effect exists when combining Pt nanoparticles and titania nanotubes. Neither Pt itself nor as-prepared titania gives the same conversion effect as demonstrated by platinized nanotubes. In the CO concentration range of 1–6% we should state the zero-order reaction according to observed data, because of the independence of the reaction rate on compound concentration. It would mean that the total active surface of the catalyst participated in the process is occupied by CO molecules. The CO conversion on the Pt/TiO2 nanotube catalyst as a function of temperature is shown in Fig. 7 . In the first run of the process, the conversion started at 30–40°C. The stationary activity of the probe is achieved at about 120°C only. Annealing of Pt/TiO2 nanotubes at 400°C in air results in some activity loss by the catalyst (Fig. 7a), as similarly happens in the catalytic reactor due to self-heating of the probe—as described in details below. Nevertheless, both the titania-supported platinum catalysts are much more active than α-Al2O3-supported platinum. This means that platinum nanoparticles remain still active after mild heating of titania nanotube support and adsorbed water removal, most probably due to an excellent cohesion of Pt particles with such a support. We studied the effect of local overheating on catalytic activity loss for the nanotubes, as reported for many other catalysts. Indeed, at high reagent concentration the heterogeneous process over Pt/TiO2 nanotubes was accompanied in our case by a strong exothermic effect leading to gas mixture burning. As a result, the temperature in the reactor increased sometimes up to 800°C, and then decreased slowly down to 120±10°C. The self-heating above 500°C would result in destroying the nanotube structure, Pt nanoparticle coarsening and probably Pt–Ti intermetallide formation, according to Tauster et al. [22]. Indeed, the mean diameter of Pt-nanoparticles increased from 3nm to 7±5nm (Fig. 8a) after a catalytic reaction due to nanoparticle melting and consolidating [23]. The same effect has been recently observed for other Pt/TiO2 composites [24]. XRD data (Fig. 2d) demonstrate a loss of some sharp reflections observed for the Pt/TiO2 nanotubes composite due to thermal destruction of titanic acid motives. Moreover, a treatment of the platinized nanotubes at 800°C for 12h resulted in a deep loss of catalytic activity of platinized nanotubes. The CO conversion over such a sample starts at 260°C only, which is very close to the result observed for Pt/α-Al2O3. The TEM micrographs (Fig. 8b) demonstrated no nanotubes after sintering at 800°C, since the material attains a rutile-type structure according to XRD (Fig. 2e, see also Refs. [9,25]). The micrograph of the platinized rutile calcined for 12h at 800°C is demonstrated in Fig. 8c. In both the cases formation of large particles of Pt is observed. To verify the assumption that Pt–Ti intermetallide could form, XPS spectra of Pt/TiO2 nanotubes catalyst after CO oxidation were recorded (Fig. 9 ), the corresponding binding energies for Pt 4f and O 1s cores are summarized in Table 2 . The study of the surface changes by XPS demonstrated a shift of some shoulders. We observed three shoulders of the O 1s core for as-synthesized Pt/TiO2 nanotubes, corresponding to O 1s cores of Ti–O–Ti, Ti–O–H and H–O–H oxygen atoms respectively (Fig. 9a, line 1, see Table 2 for fitting values). The sample sintered at 500°C had two shoulders that evidences for the presence of only two types of oxygen, presumably, Ti–O–Ti and Ti–O–H. The XRD data for this sample did not show the disappearance of (00l) H2Ti3O7 peaks (Fig. 2a). Therefore, the observed change of Ti 2p shoulders for the corresponding sample could correlate with the release of structural water and disappearing of O–H groups of titanic acid, as also confirmed by Fig. 3. A probe of Pt/TiO2 nanotubes after the CO conversion process (heating up to 800°C) demonstrated obvious structural changes originating from titanic acid decomposition (Fig. 2a). The XPS spectra of the same probe showed only one rather sharp O 1s peak of structural Ti–O–Ti oxygen. A small shift of the line to the left on 1eV could be the result of recrystallization processes. The peaks from Pt 4f core were not so intensive (Fig. 9b) because of the low concentration of platinum in the samples. The spectra of initial Pt/TiO2 nanotubes demonstrated two oxidation rates of platinum (Table 2). Two peaks indicate two oxidation states of platinum. The Pt 4f7/2 line of destination is between the binding energies of platinum oxides PtO2 (74.6eV) and PtO (72.4eV), according to the NIST database [26]. The platinum XPS spectra of the same probe after the catalytic reactor revealed only one oxidation state of platinum (Fig. 9b). We have fitted the Pt 4f5/2 and Pt 4f7/2 by Gaussians with the center positions at 74.63(2)eV and 71.23(2)eV. The positions of Pt 4f7/2 peaks correspond to metallic platinum (71.1(2)eV) or intermetallide Pt3Ti (71.3(2)eV) [20]. Thus, the observed decrease of catalytic activity of Pt/TiO2 nanotubes seems to happen due to an interaction of platinum nanoparticles with the support, resulting in intermetallic compound Pt3Ti [22]. This reaction could occur starting at 500°C and would be responsible for the decrease of activity after the first run. However, the stationary activity of the probes is similar to the activity of the probe sintered at 400°C. This observation does not confirm the platinum component degradation. The objective reason of activity loss could be dehydratation of titania nanotubes. Another possible way of platinum transformation is a chemical reduction by H2, generated in a WGS reaction at hydrated TiO2 nanotubes. However, this process was not confirmed. It is known that an oxide-based support in the model of CO oxidation on a two-phase catalyst plays the role of oxygen-ions carrier to platinum particles surfaces [27], or the role of CO adsorbent [16]. However, coarsened titania particles and relatively large Pt particles and/or intermetallic compounds formed at high temperature have to decrease the catalytic activity. On the other hand, the TPD-CO analysis of supported platinum demonstrated the CO desorption at about 80°C [17]. Combining all these factors makes us conclude that the CO oxidation occurs for the first time (the first run) over oxidized platinum at room temperature and then over reduced platinum above 120°C. In addition, a change in character of metal–support interaction takes place. This suggests that platinized nanotubes can be used as an effective catalyst at low temperatures only, since such working conditions can provide a practical benefit of nanotubes as a new support for nanodispersed platinum. 4 Summary An analysis of catalytic activities of the TiO2 supported platinum catalysts showed some advantages of TiO2 nanotubes compared to either rutile or anatase powders, expressed as a decrease of conversion temperature and an increase of specific surface area. The preliminary calcination of Pt/TiO2 nanotubes at 400°C leads to a stationary activity of the material at 120°C. The degradation of Pt/TiO2 nanotubes catalyst could occur as a result of a large exothermic effect and self-heating, leading to platinum nanoparticles agglomeration and coarsening, changes of TiO2 nanotubes structure, and possibly the interaction of Pt particles with TiO2 support, resulting in Pt3Ti intermetallide formation. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic activity of TiO2 nanotubes and titania-supported platinum catalysts was examined for carbon monoxide oxidation process. It is shown that titania nanotubes modified with 1.5wt.% of 1–5nm platinum clusters reveal notable catalytic activity already at room temperature contrary to titania or platinum itself. The catalyst behavior was analyzed using TEM, XRD and XPS techniques to find out if structural peculiarities of titania nanotubes may contribute to the catalysis at low temperatures.
coredata.dc:title: Titania nanotubes supported platinum catalyst in CO oxidation process
